Did you know the #CSSWG extended the :nth-of-type/:nth-child selectors to be much more powerful?

Safari shipped support for these new superpowers in 2015! https://caniuse.com/css-nth-child-of

But none of the other browsers did… so you probably haven’t heard about it.

If we shift from publishing in journals to posting preprints...how do we get feedback on our work?

One group's solution is to create "Preprint Clubs", where communities of academics host regular journal clubs where they review and then post their reviews online: https://www.preprintclub.com

Preprints rated most favourably by the group are then featured in a participating journal.

via https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.01.04.522570

People write about TikTok's "for you" recommendations as "eerily good", "mind reading", "spooky" -- and it does seem considerably better than its social-media rivals

But odds are there's nothing remarkable about the algorithm itself

Recommender systems are pretty mature -- it's unlikely (though not impossible) Bytedance found some new concept nobody else knows

No, the secret ingredient is more likely ...

... the UI:

People write about TikTok's "for you" recommendations as "eerily good", "mind reading", "spooky" -- and it does seem considerably better than its social-media rivals

But odds are there's nothing remarkable about the algorithm itself

Recommender systems are pretty mature -- it's unlikely (though not impossible) Bytedance found some new concept nobody else knows

No, the secret ingredient is more likely ...

... the UI:

Visual cortex is affected by sounds. Does this mean it is multisensory? Does it represent sounds?

Today in Nature #Neuroscience (https://doi.org/10.1038/s41593-022-01227-x) Célian Bimbard and team find otherwise.

Sound-evoked activity in visual cortex was similar across neurons. Even neurons in hippocampus. It persisted after we cut fibers from auditory cortex!

This activity was predicted by… subtle body movements evoked by the sounds. It reflects brainwide state and behavior signals.

#NeuroNewPaper

...
and now we have very systematic evidence of it from this paper. Check out the paper here:
https://www.nber.org/system/files/working_papers/w30826/w30826.pdf

title: J.D. Vance and the Myth of White Exceptionalism

last_post.content:
American boosters like to point out how many people are trying to get into America--how can things be so bad, if so many people desire it?

This piece made me rethink what's attractive. Perhaps people don't come to be safe or equal (but it's complex, I realize) but to be white--to belong to the dominant caste. That's the opportunity, the aspiration.

It was a quote from James Baldwin that did it: “No one was white before he or she came to America.”

https://newlinesmag.com/argument/j-d-vance-and-the-myth-of-white-exceptionalism/
